title: 'Immense' risks in outsourcing visa processing
text:
A Senate committee is considering changes to government administration and service delivery models, including outsourcing from government departments and the controversial robo-debt welfare recovery model.

Mr Rizvi, a former immigration deputy secretary with responsibility for the design and delivery of visas and citizenship programs, said a staffing cap was being imposed on Home Affairs at the same time as significant growth in via applications and revenue.

With decades of experience in the public service, he warned private providers will be under pressure to increase revenue through higher charges and a bigger caseload, contrary to the public interest.

"The Prime Minister and the minister for immigration must be open with the Australian public on the business case, risk management plan and key performance indicators for privatisation before signing any contracts," Mr Rizvi said.

"If the privatisation proceeds, the contract must include a pathway and mechanism for the government to re-acquire the IT platform at reasonable cost, if the privatisation fails.

"The contract must also expressly prohibit introduction of a premium service channel; sale or use of data for any commercial purposes; and use of the IT platform to direct users to other commercial service providers."

The Migration Institute told the inquiry immigration was a vital factor in the strength and prosperity of the country that shouldn't be put at risk.

"The privatisation of Australia’s visa and citizenship program delivery model will reduce the integrity of the processing system, increase costs to users of the system and make the protection of sensitive data and national security more difficult.

Advertisement

"All factors that have the potential to negatively impact on migration levels."

Home Affairs said the changes were not being undertaken to make budget savings and existing staff would be re-deployed to meet growing demand across other functions of its work.

In a submission to the inquiry, the department said about 50 IT systems were used for visa processing, with the two key networks more than 25-years-old.

"[A]lthough these systems remain stable and supported, it is increasingly difficult to implement policy changes, new visa categories and adjustments to complex risk assessments," the department said.

On Monday it was revealed migrants are waiting an average of 410 days for the processing of visas, up from 167 days in financial year 2013.

The government's new Services Australia department, the largest in the federal bureaucracy, said the government-wide staffing cap was leading to spending on private contractors in the administration of social security systems.

"The ability to access contractors and consultants with highly specialised skills helps us to meet needs that are difficult to address through reassigning staff internally, or through APS recruitment," the department said.
description: A former Immigration Department executive says artificial budget constraints and ageing IT systems shouldn't prompt an outsourcing of visa processing.
